facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 188 of 1961 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 188 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 11,1959,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, Patiala passed judgment and order dated September 11, 1959 in Reference No. 30 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: of the Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, Patiala in Reference No. 30 of 1957. S. Pathak, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants.

facts.text: Government of Punjab referred disputes on February 14, 1955 under s. 10(1)(c) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 to Industrial Tribunal Punjab, Jullundur as Reference No. 3 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that on February 14,,1955, the Government of Punjab referred under s. 10 1  c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act,

facts.text: Punjab Government issued Notification on April 19, 1957 extending the period of the Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, Jullundur up to last day of October 1957.

facts.text: Punjab Government issued Notification on April 19, 1957 under s. 7A constituting Industrial Tribunal with Headquarters at Jullundur and appointing Shri Avtar Narain Gujral as Presiding Officer up to June 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date on which the above Notification was issued, that is on April 19, 1957, the Government of Punjab issued a Notification under s. 7A of the Act

facts.text: Under s. 7C(b) enacted by Amendment Act 1956, age of retirement fixed at sixty-five years; Shri A.N. Gujral to retire on June 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The significance of that date is that, under s. 7C  b  enacted by the Amendment Act, 1956, the age of retirement for members was fixed at sixty-five,

facts.text: Punjab Legislature enacted Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957 amending s. 7C(b) to raise age of retirement to sixty-seven years.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Legislature intervened at this stage and enacted two statutes which are material for the present dispute. One of them was the Industrial Disputes

facts.text: Punjab Government enacted Industrial Disputes (Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions) (Punjab Amendment) Act 9 of 1957 introducing s. 30(2) to allow re-constitution of tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: The second statute enacted by the Punjab Government is the Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions   Punjab Amendment  Act 9 of 1957.

facts.text: Punjab Government issued Notification on October 31, 1957 transferring matters from old Tribunal to new Tribunal under s. 33B(1) and s. 30.

anchor.surface_text: the Government of Punjab issued on October 31, 1957 a Notification transferring the matters pending before the old Tribunal companystituted under s. 7

facts.text: Reference No. 3 of 1955 transferred and renumbered as Reference No. 30 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this Notification, Reference No. 3 of 1955 was transferred to the new Tribunal and was renumbered as 30 of 1957.

facts.text: Shri A.N. Gujral retired on June 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The present reference 30 of 1957 was pending till June 3, 1959, when Sbri A.N. Gujral retired.

facts.text: Punjab Government appointed Sri Kesho Ram Passey, retired Judge of Punjab High Court, as Presiding Officer of Industrial Tribunal, Jullundur.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Government then issued a Notification appointing Sri Kesho Ram Passey, retired Judge of the Punjab High Court as the Presiding Officer

facts.text: Appellant filed application on September 4, 1959 raising preliminary objections.

anchor.surface_text: Before him, the present appellant filed an application on September 4, 1959, raising a number of preliminary objections to the hearing of the reference.

facts.text: Tribunal overruled preliminary objections by Order dated September 11, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: By its Order dated September 11, 1959, the Tribunal overruled these objections and posted the. matter for hearing on the merits.

facts.text: Appeal heard on February 8, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Bawa Shivcharan Singh and Janardan Slwrma for the respondents. 1962. February 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKITARAMA AIYAR, J.-This is an appeal

issues.text: Whether Shri A. N. Gujral was qualified under s. 7(3)(c) of the Act to be appointed as Industrial Tribunal on August 29, 1953, despite being over sixty years of age?

anchor.surface_text: The main contention pressed before us on behalf of the appellant is that Shri A.N. Gujral was not qualified under s. 7 3 c of the Act under which the Notification was issued to be appointed as Tribunal on August 29, 1953, as he was very sixty years of age on that date, having been born on June 4, 1 892, and that there was therefore notTribunal validly constituted in existence

issues.text: Whether the Notification dated April 19, 1957 under s. 30 of the Amendment Act continuing Shri A. N. Gujral as Member of the Tribunal and subsequent extensions were authorised?

anchor.surface_text: under s., 33B 1 of the Act, and s. 30 of the Amendment Act 1956, the Government of Punjab issued on October 31, 1957 a Notification transferring the matters pending before the old Tribunal constituted under s. 7 to the new Tribunal constituted on April 19, 1957, under s. 7A.

issues.text: Whether the Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957 raising the retirement age to 67 years is void as offending Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: One of them was the Industrial Disputes Punjab Amendment Act 8 of. 1957. ... The appellant contends that this legislation was intended to benefit a single individual Shri A.N. Gujral, and is therefore void as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the transfer of proceedings under the Notification dated October 31, 1957 was valid?
Whether s. 30(2) as enacted by Punjab Act 9 of 1957 has retrospective operation to authorise transfer of proceedings pending before the old Tribunal on or before March 10, 1957?

anchor.surface_text: This contention is clearly untenable, because the whole object of s.30 2 is to provide for the hearing of disputes which were pending before the old Tribunal, and its operation is entirely retrospective.

arguments.claim: Shri A.N. Gujral was not qualified under s. 7(3)(c) of the Act to be appointed as Tribunal on August 29, 1953, as he was over sixty years of age

anchor.surface_text: The main contention pressed before us on behalf of the appellant is that Shri A.N. Gujral was not qualified under s. 7 3  c  of the Act under which the Notification was issued to be appointed as Tribunal on August 29, 1953, as he was very sixty years of age on that date, having been born on June 4, 1 892, and that there was therefore noTribunal validly constituted in existence, and that consequently the reference, to that so-called Tribunal on February 14, 55, was wholly inoperative.

arguments.court_reasoning: s. 7(3)(c) does not import any qualification based on age; age is condition of tenure not qualification for appointment; agrees with Prabhudayal case

arguments.claim: Notification dated April 19, 1957 under s. 30 of Amendment Act 36/1956 does not authorise continuation of Shri A.N. Gujral as Member after March 10, 1957

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant with reference to this Notification is that s. 30 of Act 36 of 1956 does not authorise the appointment of a Member to the Tribunal constituted under s. 7, and that the Notification in so far as it continued Shri A.N. Gujral. as a Member of the Tribunal after his term of office had expired on March 10, 1957, was unauthorised and void.

arguments.claim: Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957 is void as offending Art. 14 as intended to benefit single individual Shri A.N. Gujral

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that this legislation was intended to benefit a single individual Shri A.N. Gujral, and is therefore void as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution. The result, according to the appellant, is that after June 3, 1957, there was noone validly holding the office of Member of the Industrial Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Art. 217(1) lays down implied qualification for appointment as HC Judge that person should not have attained age of 60

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Pathak, learned counsel for the appellant, is that though Art. 217 1  refers, in terms, to the termination of the office of Judge, in substance, it lays down a qualification for appointment, because the appointment of a person over sixty as a Judge would clearly be repugnant to Art. 217 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Age prescription is condition governing duration/tenure not qualification; clear distinction between cl.(1) tenure and cl.(2) qualifications based on experience

arguments.claim: Insertion of age qualification in s.7C makes explicit what was implicit in s.7(3)(c)
arguments.court_reasoning: Inference does not follow; s.7C consistent with adding new provision for age of retirement in light of experience with repealed s.7

arguments.claim: Punjab Act 8/1957 offends Art.14 similar to Ameeroonissa v. Mehboob
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished; Ameeroonissa singled out individuals denying court access; here general application raising age for all

arguments.claim: Age is implied qualification under Art.217 supported by Arts.224 and 376

arguments.claim: Appointment of Shri A.N. Gujral valid under s.7(3)(c) as age not a qualification

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the Punjab High Court in Prabhudayals case  1  and hold that s. 7  3   c  does not import any qualification based on the age of the person to be appointed, and that the appointment of Shri A. N. Gujral on August 29, 1953, was valid under s. 7 3  c .

arguments.claim: Art.217 distinguishes qualification for appointment in cl.(2) from tenure condition in cl.(1)

anchor.surface_text: Explanation While Art. 217  2  prescribes the qualifications for appointment as a Judge, Art. 217 1  lays down that the Judge shall hold office until he attains the age of sixty years. ... We think that on a true construction of the article the prescription as to age is a condition attached to the duration of the office and not a qualification for appointment to it.

arguments.claim: s.7(3)(a) and (b) do not import age qualification, so neither does (c)

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 3  a  provides for the appointment of a High Court Judge... Age is clearly not a qualification under this sub-clause... It would therefore be legitimate to construe sub-cl.  c  as not importing any qualification on the ground of age.

arguments.claim: Appointment as Advocate-General under Art.165 of person over 60 valid

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Nagpur High Court held that cl.  1  of Art. 217 of the Constitution prescribed only the duration of the appointment of a Judge of the High Court and could not be construed as prescribing a qualification for his appointment.

arguments.claim: Punjab Act 8/1957 valid under Art.14 as general application

anchor.surface_text: But the impugned Act, 8 of 1957 is of general application, the age being raised to sixty-seven with reference to all persons holding the office under that section. The occasion which inspired the enactment of the statute might be the impending retirement of Shri A. N. Gujral. But that is not a ground for holding that it is discriminatory

arguments.claim: s.30(2) operates retrospectively for pending proceedings before old Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: This contention is clearly untenable, because the whole object of s.30 2  is to provide for the hearing of disputes which were pending before the old Tribunal, and its operation is entirely retrospective.

holdings.text: s. 7(3)(c) does not import any qualification based on the age of the person to be appointed, and the appointment of Shri A. N. Gujral on August 29, 1953, was valid under s. 7(3)(c)

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the Punjab High Court in Prabhudayals case  1  and hold that s. 7  3   c  does number import any qualification based on the age of the person to be appointed, and that the appointment of Shri A. N. Gujral on August 29, 1953, was valid under a. 7  3  c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and harmonious interpretation distinguishing Art.217(2) qualifications (experience) from Art.217(1) tenure condition (age 60); consistent with s.7(3)(a),(b); follows Prabhudayal and G.D. Karkare precedents; s.7C adds explicit disqualification not implicit in s.7

holdings.text: The Notification dated April 19, 1957 under s.30 extending the Tribunal and continuing Shri A.N. Gujral was authorised and valid

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance in this companytention. Section 30 expressly provides for the life of the Tribunal being extended for the period specified therein, and that necessarily implies a power to companytinue Shri A. N. Gujral as the Tribunal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.30 savings expressly extends Tribunal life post-repeal implying power to continue member; rendered moot by later holdings

holdings.text: Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957 is valid and does not offend Art.14
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act generally applicable raising retirement age for all presiding officers to 67, not singling out individual; motive irrelevant if classification reasonable; distinguishes Ameeroonissa (denied court access to specific persons)

holdings.text: s.30(2) (as amended by Punjab Act 9 of 1957) has retrospective operation authorising reconstitution and transfer of proceedings pending before old Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: This companytention is clearly untenable, because the whole object of s.30 2  is to provide for the hearing of disputes which were pending before the old Tribunal, and its operation is entirely retrospective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive: entire object to save pending disputes before ended Tribunals; expressly 'immediately before commencement' but applies retrospectively to enable adjudication

holdings.text: Notification dated October 31, 1957 transferring proceedings from old to new Tribunal valid

anchor.surface_text: This companytention must there. fore be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from prior holdings rejecting invalidity of new Tribunal and confirming retrospective s.30(2); both grounds of attack fail

precedents.cited_proposition: clause 1 of Article 217 prescribes only the duration of the appointment of a Judge of the High Court and cannot be construed as prescribing a qualification for his appointment
precedents.cited_holding: The learned Judges of the Nagpur High Court held that cl.  1  of Art. 217 of the Constitution prescribed only the duration of the appointment of a Judge of the High Court and companyld number be companystrued as prescribing a qualification for his appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Prabhudayal v. State of Punjab  1

precedents.cited_proposition: the prescription as to age in Art. 217  1  was number a qualification to the office of a Judge under Art. 217 2 , and that a person who was more than sixty was qualified for appointment under s. 7 3  c
precedents.cited_holding: The Court held approving of the decision in G. D. Karkares case  2 , that the prescription as to age in Art. 217  1  was number a qualification

anchor.surface_text: Ameeroonissa v. Mehboob  1

precedents.cited_proposition: legislation which singles out one or more individuals and denies them the right of resort to courts violates Article 14
precedents.cited_holding: the legislation related to the estate of one Nawab Waliuddoula, and it provided that the claims of Mahboob Begum and Kadiran Begum, who claimed as heirs stood dismissed thereby and companyld number be called in question in any companyrt of law. And this Court held that it was repugnant to Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: This contention must therefore be rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: All preliminary objections raised by appellant to jurisdiction of Tribunal rejected; correctness of Tribunal's order dated September 11, 1959 upheld

a14 distinction in Art.217 supports holding on no age qual in s.7(3)(c)

a15 argues no age qualification in s.7(3)(a)/(b) so neither in (c), supporting the concept
a15 analogy from (a)/(b) supports holding validity under (c)
Argument a15 on no age qualification in s.7(3)(a) and (b) extending to (c) addresses the issue
